title: Intuition behind Lorentz transformations
text:
In classical non-relativistic physics we deal with vectors in Euclidean space \(\mathbb{R}^3\) while in relativistic physics 4-vectors from Minkowski space \(\mathbb{R}^{1,3}\) appear (Jackson 1999).
Physical objects are usually described with these vectors or tensors of higher rank. Objects themselves do not depend on the used inertial reference frame but their coordinates do. Since physics shouldn’t depend on the choice of inertial reference frame, we want to switch between different reference frames (e.g., lab and rest frame). These frames should preserve the norm of the vector.

Code
# code Lorentz transformation
import numpy as np

def get_Lorentz_boost(zeta):
    return np.array([[np.cosh(zeta), -np.sinh(zeta)],
                     [-np.sinh(zeta), np.cosh(zeta)]])

x = np.array([1,0])[:,None]
zeta = 1
L = get_Lorentz_boost(zeta)
x_boosted = L @ x
print(x_boosted)
print(x_boosted[0]**2 - x_boosted[1]**2)
